segment.source: Bare metal reset/recovery: create recovery media while deploying new devices
segment.target: Bare metal reset/recovery: create recovery media while deploying new devices

segment.source: Bare metal reset/recovery: create recovery media while deploying new devices
segment.target: Bare metal reset/recovery: create recovery media while deploying new devices

segment.source: Bare metal reset/recovery: create recovery media while deploying new devices
segment.target: Bare metal reset/recovery: create recovery media while deploying new devices

segment.source: Recovery media (bare metal recovery) helps restore a Windows device to the factory state, even if the user needs to replace the hard drive or completely wipe the drive clean.
segment.target: Recovery media (bare metal recovery) helps restore a Windows device to the factory state, even if the user needs to replace the hard drive or completely wipe the drive clean.

segment.source: You can include this media with new devices that you provide to your customers using the same Windows images used to deploy the devices.
segment.target: You can include this media with new devices that you provide to your customers using the same Windows images used to deploy the devices.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The PC firmware/BIOS must be configured so that the PC can boot from the media (USB drive or DVD drive).
segment.target: The PC firmware/BIOS must be configured so that the PC can boot from the media (USB drive or DVD drive).

segment.source: The USB flash drive or DVD recovery media must have enough space for the Windows image.
segment.target: The USB flash drive or DVD recovery media must have enough space for the Windows image.

segment.source: If the Windows images are larger than 32GB or are larger the media you're using (for example, 4.7GB DVDs), you'll need to split the Windows image file to span across multiple DVDs.
segment.target: If the Windows images are larger than 32GB or are larger the media you're using (for example, 4.7GB DVDs), you'll need to split the Windows image file to span across multiple DVDs.

segment.source: To create a bootable USB recovery drive for a personal device, see Create a USB recovery drive.
segment.target: To create a bootable USB recovery drive for a personal device, see Create a USB recovery drive.

segment.source: Create a bootable Windows RE image
segment.target: Create a bootable Windows RE image

segment.source: To create the recovery media that you can include with the PC, you must have the following:
segment.target: To create the recovery media that you can include with the PC, you must have the following:

segment.source: A Windows image (Install.wim).
segment.target: A Windows image (Install.wim).

segment.source: You can either use the base Windows image or a customized recovery image.
segment.target: You can either use the base Windows image or a customized recovery image.

segment.source: A Windows RE tools image (Winre.wim).
segment.target: A Windows RE tools image (Winre.wim).

segment.source: You can either extract the base Windows RE tools image from the Windows image, or use a customized Windows RE image.
segment.target: You can either extract the base Windows RE tools image from the Windows image, or use a customized Windows RE image.

segment.source: Step 1: Open the Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment
segment.target: Step 1: Open the Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment

segment.source: Download and install the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (ADK).
segment.target: Download and install the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (ADK).

segment.source: On your technician PC: Click Start, and type deployment.
segment.target: On your technician PC: Click Start, and type deployment.

segment.source: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.
segment.target: Right-click Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment and then select Run as administrator.

segment.source: Step 2: Extract the Windows RE image from the Windows image
segment.target: Step 2: Extract the Windows RE image from the Windows image

segment.source: Mount the Windows image:
segment.target: Mount the Windows image:

segment.source: Copy the Windows RE image.
segment.target: Copy the Windows RE image.

segment.source: Unmount the Windows image:
segment.target: Unmount the Windows image:

segment.source: Step 3: Create a working folder for Windows RE files
segment.target: Step 3: Create a working folder for Windows RE files

segment.source: Create a folder structure for Windows RE, which is based on Windows PE:
segment.target: Create a folder structure for Windows RE, which is based on Windows PE:

segment.source: where amd64 is the architecture of the system you are creating media for.
segment.target: where amd64 is the architecture of the system you are creating media for.

segment.source: Replace the default Windows PE boot image (Boot.wim) with a Windows RE tools image.
segment.target: Replace the default Windows PE boot image (Boot.wim) with a Windows RE tools image.

segment.source: Step 4: Add the Windows image
segment.target: Step 4: Add the Windows image

segment.source: Copy the Windows image to the working folder.
segment.target: Copy the Windows image to the working folder.

segment.source: where D:sourcesinstall.wim is either the base Windows image or a customized push-button reset recovery image.
segment.target: where D:sourcesinstall.wim is either the base Windows image or a customized push-button reset recovery image.

segment.source: Step 5: Optional: Add bare metal recovery configuration scripts
segment.target: Step 5: Optional: Add bare metal recovery configuration scripts

segment.source: If you're using a customized partition layout, add bare metal recovery configuration scripts to the working folder, under sources.
segment.target: If you're using a customized partition layout, add bare metal recovery configuration scripts to the working folder, under sources.

segment.source: For more info, see Bare Metal Reset/Recovery: Enable Your Users to Create Media.
segment.target: For more info, see Bare Metal Reset/Recovery: Enable Your Users to Create Media.

segment.target: Create bootable media

segment.target: To create a bootable USB flash drive:

segment.target: where F is the drive letter of the USB flash drive.

segment.source: Label the USB flash drive with a descriptive name:
segment.target: Label the USB flash drive with a descriptive name:

segment.source: In File Explorer, right-click the drive, and select Rename, and type Full-PC Recovery.
segment.target: In File Explorer, right-click the drive, and select Rename, and type Full-PC Recovery.

segment.target: To create a bootable DVD:

segment.target: Create a DVD image file:

segment.source: Insert a DVD.
segment.target: Insert a DVD.

segment.source: In File Explorer, navigate to , right-click , and then click Burn disc image.
segment.target: In File Explorer, navigate to , right-click , and then click Burn disc image.

segment.source: Test the bare metal recovery features
segment.target: Test the bare metal recovery features

segment.source: On a PC with an empty hard drive, insert your new recovery media.
segment.target: On a PC with an empty hard drive, insert your new recovery media.

segment.source: Start the PC, press a key to open the firmware boot menus, and then select the appropriate boot device.
segment.target: Start the PC, press a key to open the firmware boot menus, and then select the appropriate boot device.

segment.source: At the Windows RE Tools menus, select a keyboard layout, for example, US.
segment.target: At the Windows RE Tools menus, select a keyboard layout, for example, US.

segment.source: Click TroubleshootReset your PCNext
segment.target: Click TroubleshootReset your PCNext

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If you are testing on the same PC, and you have not cleaned the hard drive, you may be prompted to select a drive.
segment.target: If you are testing on the same PC, and you have not cleaned the hard drive, you may be prompted to select a drive.

segment.source: Select Windows 10.
segment.target: Select Windows 10.

segment.source: Select Yes, repartition the drivesJust remove my filesReset.
segment.target: Select Yes, repartition the drivesJust remove my filesReset.

segment.source: Windows resets the computer to its original state by using the recovery image.
segment.target: Windows resets the computer to its original state by using the recovery image.

segment.source: Large-Scale Deployment
segment.target: Large-Scale Deployment

segment.source: If you are deploying USB keys with your computers, you can create a basic copy of the Windows recovery media on USB by using the steps above.
segment.target: If you are deploying USB keys with your computers, you can create a basic copy of the Windows recovery media on USB by using the steps above.

segment.source: After you have performed final customization of the image, you can boot the computer to Windows PE, and update the install.wim image on the USB recovery media.
segment.target: After you have performed final customization of the image, you can boot the computer to Windows PE, and update the install.wim image on the USB recovery media.

segment.source: You can potentially save manufacturing time by appending the Windows image on the USB flash drive, rather than recapturing the entire Windows image.
segment.target: You can potentially save manufacturing time by appending the Windows image on the USB flash drive, rather than recapturing the entire Windows image.

segment.source: If you do this, you must also update the ResetConfig.xml configuration file element: to the appropriate index number.
segment.target: If you do this, you must also update the ResetConfig.xml configuration file element: to the appropriate index number.

segment.source: For more information, see Append a Volume Image to an Existing Image Using DISM and ResetConfig XML Reference.
segment.target: For more information, see Append a Volume Image to an Existing Image Using DISM and ResetConfig XML Reference.
